text:
BRIAN KENNY: Hello, and welcome
to Managing Through Crisis.

The webcast where we bring you
insights of Harvard Business

School faculty to help managers
lead their teams and firms
through the COVID-19 crisis.

It's April 24, and
parts of the US

are deep into their second
month of self-isolation.

And confirmed COVID-19 cases
are approaching the million
mark in this country.

Testing has definitely
ramped up in many places.

But one issue that
still remains is

a lack of access to personal
protective equipment

for frontline
health care workers,

this term PPE that we've all
become used to hearing now.

Just this week Time
published the results

of a survey of 978
hospitals across 47 states

and the findings were
astonishing really.

61% had less than a
week's worth of N95 masks.

More than half had less than a
week's worth of surgical masks.

And 67% had less than a
week's worth of thermometers,
and that list went on and on.

The situation is really
dire, to the extent

that some people have decided
that it's time to take matters
into their own hands.

One of those people
is here with us today.
I'm happy to welcome Sophie Bai.

Sophie, is in her second year
at Harvard Business School.

She hails from China
originally but she's

been in the Boston area
for the past decade or so.

And she is the founder of
People First, that's people
spelled P-P-E People First.

And we're going to talk
more about what people first

is all about, that's what
we're here to talk about today.

Also joining us today
is Jeff Bussgang.

Jeff, is a Professor at
Harvard Business School.

And in addition to teaching
entrepreneurship at HBS,

he is the Co-founder
and General Partner
at Flybridge Capital Partners.

And he's been helping Sophie
and People First get up
and running.

Thank you both for
joining me today.
It's great to have you.
BOTH: Thank you for having us.

BRIAN KENNY: So, we've got
a lot to talk about Sophie.

You've been hard at work
for several weeks now

and I've seen a lot of
publicity around what you've

been doing so you're
really getting

people's attention around
a really important topic

that I was just sort of teeing
up there in the introduction.

But I need you to
start maybe by just

describing for our viewers
what's People First?
What's your mission?

And what kind of impact have
you been able to make so far?

SOPHIE BAI: Yeah,
so People First
is a group of HBS students.

We came together as
volunteers trying

to solve the problem of the
massive PPE shortage happening
here in Boston area.

So we're procuring the PPE
that is much needed from China

and deliver it to the
hospitals and frontline workers
in the Boston area.
So that is what we do.

And so far, we have been
able to raise $3 million

and converted into 1.7
million pieces of PPE

that are being distributed
or in the process

of being distributed to
frontline workers here
in Boston.

BRIAN KENNY: And that's
going to hospitals

all around the
greater Boston area?
SOPHIE BAI: Correct.

So we have distributed to
more than 12 institutions,

including larger hospitals
like MDH, Brigham and Women's,

Beth Israel, Boston
Medical Center,

but also including some senior
facilities like Hebrew Senior

Life and some of the
smaller clinics as well.

BRIAN KENNY: So there's
a real lesson in here

and this is part of the reason
that we've invited Jeff on.

Not just the fact that
he's working with you,

but he's an expert and
startups and entrepreneurship.

I do want to talk about
the kinds of things

that you faced while you've sort
of entered into this startup
enterprise.

What was your-- let
me just ask you, what
made you decide to do this?

You were just sort of
sitting around in quarantine

and said, I see a problem,
I need to solve it.

SOPHIE BAI: So
when HBS announced

post spring break that
classes are moving online

I started to realize
that the situation is
getting more and more serious.

And a lot of my
friends from undergrad

are actually currently
doctors in Women's Brigham

and they're telling me the
dire situation about the PPE
shortage they are facing.

They had been reusing or
recycling masks for weeks.

So that's when I started to know
there is a huge problem here.

And my friends back home in
China who's family businesses

have been large medical
supply distribution.

So I was just trying to connect
the dots there is a need here

and then there is a
supply there in China.

So I just want I think
there's a way to help

BRIAN KENNY: So Jeff let me
turn to you for a minute.

Just tell us how
did you get involved

and what role have you been
playing with People First?

JEFF BUSSGANG: Yeah,
Sophie came to me

to share with me her passion
for this concern and the fact
that she could help.

And so I began to
work with her and have

had the pleasure of working
with her and her team which she

fondly calls the
elves, Sophie's elves,
for the last couple of weeks.

And just as you said
it's been like a startup

and we can get into how
amazing these students

have been under
Sophie's leadership

in creating this multimillion
dollar medical distribution

business from scratch out of the
Harvard dorms in under a month.

But I've had just the
pleasure of helping,

in particular connect her with
a lot of the folks in the Boston

community who could help and
provide some of the support

for the system that
she's trying to design.

Whether it's a foundation like
the Boston Foundation, which

has been the entity that
stood up the nonprofit to

accumulate the money
and the donations.

Or a fintech, like
Flywire which has helped

send the dollars very quickly
and convert them into rnb
into China.

Or a warehouse company
Grossman Marketing

who served as our warehouse
and logistics partner.

So using my network in
Boston and linking up

with the students
and Sophie's work

has been really the
focus that I've had.

BRIAN KENNY: Sophie,
let me ask you,

I'm just curious as to how
you even knew where to begin
and doing something like this?

Most people that are
home in quarantine

appear to be
watching Tiger King.

You know, you obviously have
a lot more ambition than that.

But like where do you even--
like you see a problem
you know you want to solve it.

How do you even
know where to start?

SOPHIE BAI: Well first I
don't have a TV in my dorm,

so I can't really
watch Tiger King.

But, so I reached
out to my friend

first asking what is the
supply available right,

now given the situation in
China had been contained,

that a lot of the focus has
been supplying internationally.

And her family business
has been supporting

some other governments out there
so I got a list of supplies

that she could able to
provide and I reached out

to Professor Bussgang, as
well as my MIT professor Bob

Langer, who connect me to some
senior folks at the Brigham
Women's Hospital.

That's how we first
started to test out
a first order with Brigham.

So Jeff had been really
enabling us to work really fast,

to be able to get supplies
for Brigham and to start.

And then after we have
seen the supplies cleared

Chinese custom,
cleared US custom,

and arrived to break them
safely just within eight days,

we were really excited
to ramp this effort up

and to get more donations, to
get more capital to scale up
to other hospitals as well.

BRIAN KENNY: So Jeff, as
you've been working with Sophie

and her team, are
there particular things

that you see here that have
helped them to be successful?

Or are there sort of
certain ingredients

that they've been able
to tap into that you

see are kind of the
important things for success
of an endeavor like this?

JEFF BUSSGANG: Well first
of all, Sophie and her team

are very, very uniquely
suited for this problem.

If you go into the
procurement department

of a typical hospital in Boston
and you find a middle manager

sitting in a cubicle who's used
to purchasing supplies from DJs

or Costco they don't
speak Mandarin,

they're not up all
night on WeChat,

they don't have relationships
with the White Label Medical
Distributors in China.

They're not accustomed to
the dynamic environment which

is today more like a
commodities trading floor

than a well-organized
procurement process.

So there's a complete
mismatch between the way

that PPE procurement
is happening today

in a very competitive dynamic
global environment mainly

in China, and the
way that the hospital

systems in the US
and the governments

as well have been set up to do
very normal run of the mill,
state of the art procurement.

And so Sophie's
team has completely

bridged that gap between
those two methods.

And then the second
thing I would observe

is that they're doing
it like a startup.

They're taking a page out of
the TDM first year playbook.

Running experiments, operating
very dynamically very

creatively and very
entrepreneurially.

And so those two things that
sort of new dynamic procurement

system that they've been able to
stand up and then the approach

of taking one step
at a time experiments

and willingness to fail,
willingness to try new things,

has been really what's
made this so successful.

BRIAN KENNY: Sophie, what are
the things that have surprised
you along the way here?

Both in a good
way and a bad way.

I'm sure you faced some
obstacles, what were those?

But also what are
the things that you

have found were sort of easier
than you thought they might be?

SOPHIE BAI: I think the
overwhelming support

that I get from my classmates
my best friends here.

As well as from Jeff who has
connected us with so many

amazing organizations
or individuals

who are willing to
help is beyond me.

Like I never thought
just within 10 days

I was working in my dorm day one
with zero capital, to by day 10

I was working with a team
of 12 of my classmates,
with more than $2 million.

That just all
happened in 10 days.

So that was a really good
or amazing surprise to me.

I guess it is
challenging, right?

It's more than moving from
goods from point A to point B,

it's way more complex than
that, because here we're
dealing with medical supplies.

There's so much
regulation around it

right both from the China
side and from the US side.

So what makes it
challenging is, it's
not a typical procurement job.

You need to understand the
technical aspects as well,

so that's part of the
medical team's job.

And also you need to understand
the custom regulations

both from the China side
and from the US side, which

has been changing every
single day, right.

So it's basically a job
combining procurement, import
export, and medical expertise.

So that's what makes
this so challenging.

So I think the number
one area that we

found challenging to
start with as Jeff said,

was the dynamic market
situation, right.

It is a seller's market,
it's a free for all

market, that we are competing
against other governments

and other countries, in this
world for the same supplies.

So the speed to cash
is really crucial.

So we were able to get the
help from Flywire which

is a Boston based fintech
to help us really speed up

the payment flow process to be
able to get those supplies as
fast as we can.
So.

You know, like I think
we have to operate

in a way have the mindset
is don't let the perfect be
the enemy of the good.

Just to get the as much as
we can at the best price

as we can, just because
be it is so crucial.

Because as some of the
health care experts

have said, that each day
delay of PPE delivery

translates into 30
Massachusetts residents dying.

So we just simply
don't have time

to wait or to run the regular
process that has been set up
here in a more traditional way.
So I will say that's number one.

Number two, I would say really
is, when you think about all

of this new factories
were built or converted

in general in China they were
really supplying domestically,
right?

So when you think about
the certification processes

or the testing processes, they
were really Chinese standards.

And Chinese standards
and FDA or US standards

are two completely
different systems.

So how do you communicate
those two systems to each other
has been challenging.

And I think has caused a lot
of challenges for the US buyers
to buy in China.

Just because beyond
the language barrier

here, then you really have to
understand the technical specs
of those masks.

Like let's take the
surgical mask for example,

the US is so used to ASTM 123
which is an American Standard,

but it doesn't exist
in China, right?

But then you have to look
into the Chinese standard

to figure out the test report
the specs of the filtration

capabilities or all
those different type of I

guess the functions
each mask have,

to be able to match
what is the equivalent,
and are those exportable?

And are those imported all
at the same time in the US?

So having that
communication back and forth

has been challenging but because
we have overcome that, I guess

made us be able to procure large
quantities in a faster way.

I think number three
really is about

trying to get the logistics
right, which I think given

the pandemic a lot of the
international flights or planes
have been canceled.

So being able to get
the stuff on the ground

from China to the US has been
a lot slower than before.

And also domestically
within the US just because

of the pandemic UPS or FedEx of
the world have cut personnel.

So sometimes the
overnight delivery

turn into three to
four days, which
delays the delivery as well.

So there are I would
say different problems

along the way that we're
facing every single day.

But we are also as a
team of problem solvers

trying to figure out
the way to solve those.

BRIAN KENNY: Let me pull the
lens back a little bit Jeff,

and ask you, it's amazing
what People First has

been able to
accomplish with Sophie

and her team have done in such
a compressed period of time.

Do conditions like the
ones that were in today

make it easier or
harder for ventures
like this to get started?

I mean, people see the problem,
does that help the situation

where there's more of a
willingness for others

to support them and the network
to kind of rally around them?

JEFFREY BUSSGANG:
I think for sure.

If you take Sophie's earlier
point about how quickly we were

able to raise $3
million that we raised,

certainly the crisis
was a catalyst for that.

And so being able to
bring capital together.
Secondly, talent.

Sophie is such a
talented person,

normally she would have so
many other demands on her time
and similar with her classmates.

But the fact that in the
middle of this crisis

they had not only capacity
but also the passion

and the desire to prioritize
this effort as such

an important priority
even above classes

and if any of their
other faculty members

that are watching
this have Sophie

or her team in their class
I hope they'll take note,

that this team has been just
working around the clock.

Again you wouldn't
be able to convene

this powerful group
of 10 HBS students

almost all women, by the
way, who really abandoned

every other thing
going on in their lives

and have put 10, 12, 14 hours
a day into this venture.

So I think the
notion of the fact

that this crisis has got
everyone's attention has been

able to allow us to pull talent
and capital together very
quickly.

BRIAN KENNY: Do you
think a situation

like this has the
potential to be

a catalyst for entrepreneurship
in the broadest

sense of the word, where we see
a new wave of entrepreneurship

coming out of a
situation like this,

where we know things
aren't going to go back
to the way they were before?

JEFFREY BUSSGANG: Yeah, I see
this in my venture capital work
at Flybridge.

There are a lot of
startups that have

emerged taking advantage of
this new trend or a new reset.

Whether it's work
from home, learn

from home, the advent of
some of the medical needs
that are being surfaced here.

We have one company
in our portfolio

that is known to probably
some of your viewers

called Lovepop, which had
been a greeting card company
up until a few weeks ago.

They pivoted to suddenly
make face shields using

their precision manufacturing
expertise and capabilities

to make PPE face shields
for local area hospitals.

There's a company up in
Lawrence, Massachusetts

that was an apparel company
doing apparel and sportswear

for Under Armor
called 99 Custom,
they pivoted to making gowns.

And they're now producing gowns
for hospitals, former Mass
Challenge company.

So there's a lot of very
dramatic creative moves

being made out there in the
entrepreneurial ecosystem.

BRIAN KENNY: So Sophie,
what has the reaction been

of the hospitals that you've
been able to help out?

SOPHIE BAI: I mean, we have
received overwhelmingly

heartwarming thank you notes
and messages from everybody.

That's from hospitals,
to families,

from doctors and nurses to
the husbands or family members
of those frontline workers.

They were telling us, you guys
are literally saving our lives.

So I think that's a
very powerful statement

we have received,
and it just makes

us feel what we're
doing have made

a very immediate and direct
impact on people's lives.

And that's what basically
keeps us going and working

around the clock and trying
to get as much as we can.

JEFFREY BUSSGANG: People
know that this disease--

if I may, just people
know this disease--

has impacted people of
color and inner cities
even more dramatically.

And just coincidentally,
just as Sophie

has friends who are
doctors and clinicians,

my daughter also has friends
in similar positions.

And we donated some PPE
to one of the facilities

where a friend of
my daughter's works,

and she called my
daughter this morning

insisting that she talked
to me to thank me so much.

And she told me that not
only did the PPE would really

help them save lives and do
a better job of screening

the patients that come
into their clinic,

but it would also allow them to
become a testing site, which is
really an extraordinary thing.

Because if you don't have the
proper protective equipment
you can't test COVID patients.

And so some of these basic goods
and supplies that are suddenly

allowing these clinics to serve
their populations even more

carefully is just really
very heartwarming.

BRIAN KENNY: Let me ask this of
both of you, do either of you

have any advice
for somebody who's

watching who might be
thinking about doing something

of their own to address
an aspect of this crisis
that they want to try and fix?
SOPHIE BAI: I'll start.

I think it is a difficult
time for everybody.

And things have
been so different

and it poses a lot of challenges
in every aspect of your life.

I would say there
are so many ways

to help out, whether from PPE or
from helping local communities,
helping local businesses.

Like we have seen many
even students on campus

have started at so many
different initiatives.

I would say my
recommendation would

be just don't think of starting
big, because I started small.

I started helping my
friends to find some masks.

And then when I approached
Jeff, and he just

put me on this rocket ship that
everything scaled so quickly,

and we were able to do
this on a larger scale.

So I think as long as you
have some idea helping people

around you, and then you will
find the resources or people

are around you who
are able to enable
you to do something greater

BRIAN KENNY: Jeff, do
you want to add anything?

JEFFREY BUSSGANG: No,
it's beautifully said.

I think starting small,
small gestures, acting local.

One of my colleagues
at Flybridge

is involved in an
organization that's

delivering meals from
takeout restaurants
to hospital workers.

It's a win-win,
because the restaurants

have some excess
capacity and they
love the idea of helping out.

And obviously, the hospital
workers and frontline

caregivers need to
be fed and cared for.

So I think anything that people
can do that are listening,

some people just
struggle sometimes
to know where to start.

But just something as
simple as delivering

a cup of coffee or
a breakfast burrito

to a hospital or caregiver
would be just an amazing way
to start.

And then you never know
where it could lead.

As Sophie said, what
had been just a kind

gesture of getting some masks
in the hands of some friends,

has now turned into
this multimillion dollar
medical distribution business.
And she has made just--

her classmates-- have made just
an extraordinary, extraordinary

impact on the Boston
community as a result.

BRIAN KENNY: So
Sophie, I'm going
to give you the last word.

Where can people reach
out to help People First?

SOPHIE BAI: Yeah, so we
have two donation links.

One is through the Boston
Foundation, the COVID-19 PPE
fund.

Another one is GoFundMe,
which is the more, I guess,
millennial friendly link.

So as you said in
the very beginning
the situation is still dire.

The state needs more than
two million pieces of N95

every single week and we are
still not at the peak yet,
right.

So it's going to be a marathon
and we're still trying
to help as much as we could.

So any help big and
small would really

help us to help the
frontline workers, to protect
themselves and save more lives.
BRIAN KENNY: That's great.

Sophie Bai and Jeff, thank you
both, for joining me today.

And I wish you continued success
with People First Sophie.

SOPHIE BAI: Thank
you so much Brian.
